passages.text: Life swings like a pendulum backward and forward between pain and boredom.
passages.source: The World as Will and Representation
passages.context: The two poles of unsatisfied existence

passages.text: The will is a blind, unconscious striving, an endless desiring that can never be satisfied.
passages.source: The World as Will and Representation

passages.text: We forfeit three-quarters of ourselves in order to be like other people.
Compassion is the basis of all morality.
passages.context: Ethics grounded in felt connection to suffering

passages.text: Talent hits a target no one else can hit; genius hits a target no one else can see.
passages.source: The World as Will and Representation
passages.context: Distinction between skill and original seeing

passages.text: Every man takes the limits of his own field of vision for the limits of the world.
The two enemies of human happiness are pain and boredom.
A man can be himself only so long as he is alone; and if he does not love solitude, he will not love freedom.
The assumption that animals are without rights and the illusion that our treatment of them has no moral significance is a positively outrageous example of Western crudity and barbarity.
Hope is the confusion of the desire for a thing with its probability.
passages.source: The World as Will and Representation

passages.text: Mostly it is loss which teaches us about the worth of things.
Every parting gives a foretaste of death; every reunion a hint of the resurrection.
passages.context: Small deaths and resurrections in daily life

passages.text: Music is the melody whose text is the world.
passages.source: The World as Will and Representation
passages.context: Music as direct expression of the will itself

passages.text: The doctor sees all the weakness of mankind; the lawyer all the wickedness, the theologian all the stupidity.
passages.context: Each profession reveals a different flaw

passages.text: Happiness consists in frequent repetition of pleasure.
To overcome difficulties is to experience the full delight of existence.
Reading is merely a surrogate for thinking for yourself; it means letting someone else direct your thoughts.
The fundament upon which all our knowledge and learning rests is the inexplicable.
passages.context: Mystery at the ground of all understanding

passages.text: After your death you will be what you were before your birth.
passages.context: Death as return to prenatal non-existence

passages.text: Almost all of our sorrows spring out of our relations with other people.
passages.context: Social life as primary source of pain
